repository.corpname: Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library

did.abstract: The Barbara Howes papers contain writings, correspondence, personal and financial papers, and photographs documenting the life and literary career of American poet and editor Barbara Howes. The collection includes extensive files on all of Howes's book-length publications and many manuscripts and typescripts of individual poems, short stories and articles; her correspondence with her family, particularly with her mother and her husband, the poet William Jay Smith; and letters from a wide circle of literary friends and colleagues, including Leonie Adams, Elizabeth Bishop, Malcolm Cowley, Denise Levertov, James Merrill, W. S. Merwin, Katherine Anne Porter, Theodore Roethke, and Richard Wilbur.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Series I-IV purchased from Ken Lopez Bookseller on the Dwight and Nathan funds, 2002. Series V is the gift of Barbara Howes, 1960-1966.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: The materials are open for research.
Box 33 (sound recordings): Restricted fragile material. Reference copies may be requested. Consult Access Services for further information.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: The Barbara Howes Papers is the physical property of the Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library, Yale University. Literary rights, including copyright, belong to the authors or their legal heirs and assigns. For further information, consult the appropriate curator.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Barbara Howes Papers. Yale Collection of American Literature, Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: The collection received preliminary processing at the time of acquisition. Further organization, rehousing, and/or description was/were carried out in 2012.

Information included in the Description of Papers note and Collection Contents section is drawn from information supplied with the collection in appraisal documentation and from an initial survey of the contents. Folder titles appearing in the contents list below are almost entirely based on those provided on the original folders and/or supplied by the dealer. Titles have not been verified against the contents of the folders in all cases. Otherwise, folder titles are supplied by staff during basic processing.
Descriptive information drawn from the dealer documentation has not been edited for stylistic consistency.
This finding aid may be updated periodically to account for new acquisitions to the collection and/or revisions in arrangement and description.

bioghist.head: Barbara Howes (1914-1996)
bioghist.p: Barbara Howes (1914-1996) was born in New York and adopted by Mr. and Mrs.Osborn Howes, Jr.of Chestnut Hill, Massachusetts. She was raised there and educated at Beaver Country Day School; she graduated from Bennington College in 1937. After working briefly for the Southern Tenant Farmers Union in Mississippi, she moved to Greenwich Village and began submitting her poems to literary magazines.

From 1943 until 1947 she was editor of Chimera , with David Newton and Ximena de Angulo. A "little magazine," the journal published poetry by John Berryman, Richard Eberhart, Randall Jarrell, Kenneth Patchen, and others, as well as articles by such authors as Carl Jung, Thomas Mann, and Henry Miller.

Howes published seven collections of poetry: The Undersea Farmer (1948); In the Cold Country (1954); Light and Dark (1959); Looking Up at Leaves (1966); The Blue Garden (1977); A Private Signal: Poems New and Selected (1977); and Moving (1983). The Collectted Poems of Barbara Howes, 1945-1990 was published in 1995.
In addition, Howes also edited the anthologies From the Green Antilles: Writings of the Caribbean (1966) and The Eye of the Heart: Short Stories from Latin America (1970).

She married the poet William Jay Smith in 1947, and they lived for a time in England and Italy before settling in Vermont. They had two sons, Gregory Jay Smith and David Smith. The couple divorced in the mid-1960s, and thereafter Howes lived mostly a secluded life on her farm in Pownal, Vermont. Barbara Howes died in Bennington, Vermont in February, 1996.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Barbara Howes papers contain writings, correspondence, personal and financial papers, and photographs documenting the life and literary career of American poet and editor Barbara Howes. The collection includes extensive files on all of Howes' book-length publications and many manuscripts and typescripts of individual poems, short stories and articles; her correspondence with her family, particularly with her mother and her husband, the poet William Jay Smith; and letters from a wide circle of literary friends and colleagues, including Leonie Adams, Elizabeth Bishop, Malcolm Cowley, Denise Levertov, James Merrill, W. S. Merwin, Katherine Anne Porter, Theodore Roethke, and Richard Wilbur.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Organized into five series: I. Writings, 1929-1991. II. Correspondence, 1922-1995. III. Personal and Financial Papers, 1914-1995. IV. Photographs, 1916-1957.V. 1960-1966 Gifts of Barbara Howes Writings, 1959-1965..

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Not arranged in any particular order.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The series contains autograph manuscript and typescript drafts of Barbara Howes' writings, along with proofs and correspondence files related to particular works and publications. In addition to files on all of Howes' book-length publications, the series also contains information on her early unpublished writings and on individual poems, stories and articles.
Most folder titles have been taken from the original folders and/or from appraisal and dealer information; most folder contents notes have been taken from the same sources.
Correspondents represented here often also appear in Series II, Correspondence .

scopecontent.p: 21 original poem manuscripts, including holograph first, second and third drafts, with some consisting of eight to ten pages each.

Poems included in this folder include "E Pur Si Muove," "Sitting Around Travelling," "Super-Inferno: Pittsfield-July," "For All Occasions," "To Fido, His Horse," "Repeating Values," "Mock-Natural Things," "Isolation Ward/ County Hospital," "All Clear By Satellite," ''The Clear Eyes of Toby," "English," "The Union of Art and Medicine," "Being Me," "Among Shells," "Dyed-In-the-Wool," "On His Life," "Sperar Temere ... ," "The Architect for H.K.A," "Sunset on Manasota Key," "Sheriff Peacher's Stockade," "Squares," and "The Fourth Step."

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Contains incoming letters and retained copies of outgoing letters. The categories "Literary Correspondence," "Family Correspondence," "Political Correspondence" and "Business Correspondence" were devised by the dealer and have been retained, although there appears to be considerable overlap in some cases. Folder titles are largely transcribed from existing folders or from appraisal or dealer descriptions.

Howes' correspondence with other authors, particularly American poets, was extensive, and correspondents include Leonie Adams, Elizabeth Bishop, Malcolm Cowley, Denise Levertov, James Merrill, W. S. Merwin, Katherine Anne Porter, Theodore Roethke, and Richard Wilbur. Family correspondence, particularly Howes' lengthy series of letters to her mother, documents Howes' personal and professional life and travels, while other files document her poetry readings, lectures, and other public appearances.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Letters written by Barbara Howes to her mother over a long period of years (1922-1951), ranging over many topics and locations, describing both her work and who she met during her travels.

Included in the letters are accounts of meeting such individuals as Dylan Thomas, T. S. Eliot, Enid Starkie, Stephen Spender, Olivia Manning, Simone de Beauvior, Caresse Crosby, Harold Acton, Bernard Berenson, Graham Greene, Tennessee Williams and Truman Capote.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Note: Ximena was a college friend of Barbara Howes from Bennington College (and coeditor of Chimera magazine) and remained a close friend throughout their lives. Cary F. Baynes, Ximena's mother, worked with Dr. Carl Jung and introduced Howes to the Jungs. Barbara attended several tagungs at the Eranos Conferences in Geneva and spent weekends with the Jungs in Ascona.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: One folder of six typewritten letters from Barbara Howes' birth father, William P. Dudley (1945-04); newspaper clippings about his suicide in 1965; two letters from Marika Dudley. Also included are Barbara Howes' adoption certificate (1914) and Baptism document (1928).

Also included are a pamphlet, "The Mid Century in Exeter" about Exeter, NH; a newspaper clipping about the death of Albertus Dudley (1955) and a hand-written note which reads "corridors of life in him had narrowed down to a handful of obsessions."

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Albums of black and white photographs taken of Barbara Howes and William Jay Smith and their sons while living in Italy, including shots of many literary figures.

Photos include shots of writers such as W. H. Auden, Leonie Adams and William Troy, Dore Ashton, Enid Starkie, Caitlin Thomas, Stephen Spender, John McCiennan, Adja Yunkers, Jack Murphy, R.P. Blackmur, Thekla Clark, Newell Jenkins, Elizabeth Mann, Jane Sabersky, etc.
